title: A Table View is a list of rows that can be selected. Each row is populated from a data source. This example creates a simple table view in which each row is a single line of text.

inline_content.Text: A Table View is a list of rows that can be selected. Each row is populated from a data source. This example creates a simple table view in which each row is a single line of text.

title: Add a UITableView to your Storyboard

inline_content.Text: Add a UITableView to your Storyboard

title: Although there are a number of ways to create a
UITableView
c
, one of the easiest is to add one to a Storyboard. Open your Storyboard and drag a
UITableView
c
onto your
UIViewController
c
. Make sure to use Auto Layout to correctly align the table (pin all four sides).

title: In order to display content dynamically (i.e. load it from a data source like an array, a Core Data model, a networked server, etc.) in your table view you need to setup the data source.

inline_content.Text: In order to display content dynamically (i.e. load it from a data source like an array, a Core Data model, a networked server, etc.) in your table view you need to setup the data source.

title: A data source could, as stated above, be anything with data. Its entirely up to you how to format it and whats in it. The only requirement is that you must be able to read it later so that you can populate each row of your table with data when needed.

inline_content.Text: A data source could, as stated above, be anything with data. Its entirely up to you how to format it and whats in it. The only requirement is that you must be able to read it later so that you can populate each row of your table with data when needed.

title: In this example, we’ll just set an array with some strings (text) as our data source:

inline_content.Text: In this example, we’ll just set an array with some strings (text) as our data source:

title: let myDataArray: [String] = ["Row one", "Row two", "Row three", "Row four", "Row five"]

content_resolved.code: let myDataArray: [String] = ["Row one", "Row two", "Row three", "Row four", "Row five"]

title:
// You'll need to define this variable as a global variable (like an @property) so that you can access it later when needed.
NSArray *myDataArray = @[@"Row one", @"Row two", @"Row three", @"Row four", @"Row five"];

content_resolved.code:
// You'll need to define this variable as a global variable (like an @property) so that you can access it later when needed.
NSArray *myDataArray = @[@"Row one", @"Row two", @"Row three", @"Row four", @"Row five"];

title: Setting up your data source in your View Controller

c
protocol.

title: tableView:numberOfRowsInSection
c
, this asks you how many rows your table view should have.

inline_content.Text: , this asks you how many rows your table view should have.

title: tableView:cellForRowAtIndexPath
c
, requests that you create and return a cell for each row you specified in
tableView:numberOfRowsInSection
c
. So, if you said you needed 10 rows, this method will be called ten times for each row, and you need to create a cell for each of those rows.

inline_content.Text: , requests that you create and return a cell for each row you specified in
. So, if you said you needed 10 rows, this method will be called ten times for each row, and you need to create a cell for each of those rows.

title: WARNING: You may NOT return nil for any cells in cellForRowAtIndexPath:. This will cause your app to crash, and you will see the following error in the console:

inline_content.Text: WARNING: You may NOT return nil for any cells in cellForRowAtIndexPath:. This will cause your app to crash, and you will see the following error in the console:

title: Uncaught exception 'NSInternalInconsistencyException', reason: 'UITableView dataSource must return a cell from tableView:cellForRowAtIndexPath:'

content_resolved.code: Uncaught exception 'NSInternalInconsistencyException', reason: 'UITableView dataSource must return a cell from tableView:cellForRowAtIndexPath:'

title: When a user taps on a row in your table view, generally, you’ll want to do something - to respond. In many apps, when you tap on a row, more information about that item you tapped upon is displayed. Think of the Messages app: when you tap on the row showing one of your contacts, the conversation with that person is then displayed on screen.

inline_content.Text: When a user taps on a row in your table view, generally, you’ll want to do something - to respond. In many apps, when you tap on a row, more information about that item you tapped upon is displayed. Think of the Messages app: when you tap on the row showing one of your contacts, the conversation with that person is then displayed on screen.

title: There are no required methods to implement for the table view’s delegate. However, to handle row selections you’ll need to use the following method:

inline_content.Text: There are no required methods to implement for the table view’s delegate. However, to handle row selections you’ll need to use the following method:

title: tableView:didSelectRowAtIndexPath
c
, this is called whenever a row is tapped, which allows you to do something in response. For our example, we’ll just print a confirmation statement to the Xcode log.

inline_content.Text: , this is called whenever a row is tapped, which allows you to do something in response. For our example, we’ll just print a confirmation statement to the Xcode log.
